standard_metadata.standard_description: Explain why a fraction a/b is equivalent to a fraction (n × a)/(n × b) by using visual fraction models, with attention to how the number and size of the parts differ even though the two fractions themselves are the same size. Use this principle to recognize and generate equivalent fractions.

hints.content: We can start with a fraction and change the way we divide the whole to make an **equivalent fraction.**  Equivalent fractions have the same area as each other.
This square has $\blueE{2}$ equal parts, with $\maroonD{1}$ part shaded. It represents $\dfrac{\maroonD{1}}{\blueE{2}}$.

images.alt: fraction with 1 of 2 equal parts shaded

hints.content: We can split up the whole square in a different way but keep the same area.     This square has $\maroonD{p}$ shaded parts, with $\blueE{4}$ equal parts. It represents $\dfrac{\maroonD{p}}{\blueE{4}}$.  How many shaded  parts are in the square?

images.alt: fraction with the same area with 2 of 4 equal parts shaded

hints.content: There are $\maroonD{2}$ shaded parts in the square, so $\maroonD{p}=\maroonD{2}$.

We can represent our work with multiplication, too. We split every part into $\purpleD{2}$ equal parts.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{\maroonD{1}}{\blueE{2}} &=\dfrac{\maroonD{1} \times \purpleD{2}}{\blueE{2}\times \purpleD{2}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\boxed{\maroonD{2}}}{{\blueE{4}}} \end{align}$  The area does not change.
$\maroonD{p}=\maroonD{2}$
We can start with a fraction and change the way we divide the whole to make an **equivalent fraction.**  Equivalent fractions have the same area as each other.
This square has $\blueE{3}$ equal parts, with $\maroonD{1}$ part shaded. It represents $\dfrac{\maroonD{1}}{\blueE{3}}$.

images.alt: fraction with 1 of 3 equal parts shaded

hints.content: We can split up the whole square in a different way but keep the same area.     This square has $\maroonD{t}$ shaded parts, with $\blueE{6}$ equal parts. It represents $\dfrac{\maroonD{t}}{\blueE{6}}$.  How many shaded  parts are in the square?

images.alt: fraction with the same area with 2 of 6 equal parts shaded

hints.content: There are $\maroonD{2}$ shaded parts in the square, so $\maroonD{t}=\maroonD{2}$.

We can represent our work with multiplication, too. We split every part into $\purpleD{2}$ equal parts.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{\maroonD{1}}{\blueE{3}} &=\dfrac{\maroonD{1} \times \purpleD{2}}{\blueE{3}\times \purpleD{2}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\boxed{\maroonD{2}}}{{\blueE{6}}} \end{align}$  The area does not change.
$\maroonD{t}=\maroonD{2}$
We can start with a fraction and change the way we divide the whole to make an **equivalent fraction.**  Equivalent fractions have the same area as each other.
This square has $\blueE{4}$ equal parts, with $\maroonD{1}$ part shaded. It represents $\dfrac{\maroonD{1}}{\blueE{4}}$.

images.alt: fraction with 1 of 4 equal parts shaded

hints.content: We can split up the whole square in a different way but keep the same area.     This square has $\maroonD{c}$ shaded parts, with $\blueE{12}$ equal parts. It represents $\dfrac{\maroonD{c}}{\blueE{12}}$.  How many shaded  parts are in the square?

images.alt: fraction with the same area with 3 of 12 equal parts shaded

hints.content: There are $\maroonD{3}$ shaded parts in the square, so $\maroonD{c}=\maroonD{3}$.

We can represent our work with multiplication, too. We split every part into $\purpleD{3}$ equal parts.  $\begin{align} \dfrac{\maroonD{1}}{\blueE{4}} &=\dfrac{\maroonD{1} \times \purpleD{3}}{\blueE{4}\times \purpleD{3}}\\\\ &= \dfrac{\boxed{\maroonD{3}}}{{\blueE{12}}} \end{align}$  The area does not change.
$\maroonD{c}=\maroonD{3}$

This square has $\blueE{10}$ equal parts, with $\maroonD{1}$ part shaded. It represents $\dfrac{\maroonD{1}}{\blueE{10}}$.

images.alt: fraction with 1 of 10 equal parts shaded
